title-group.article-title: General Purpose Reports and Users' Data Needs

abstract.p: Contemporary, external reporting policies are based primarily on the concept of general purpose reports. Such reports are designed to communicate fairly uniform financial data to a wide range of potential users. This paper examines the relevance of these general purpose reports to the information needs of statement readers. Since statement readers constitute a disparate group, serious doubt exists concerning the feasibility of satisfying their potentially diverse information needs with reports prepared using a single measurement base which relies heavily on events external to any individual firm. The author poses a series of provocative question which are intended to generate reflective inquiry into the suitability of contemporary reporting practices for their intended use.
